Well, yes, however to me it looks much more like a pattern for assertion
testing than like a pattern for unit testing. If I had to unit test
something like the controler, I would rather write own mock implementations
of greeter and sender to test the controler: By doing so I will have no
testing code in my production code. Does that seem too much of an overhead,
or for what other reason is Eric Allen's approach more promising?

Toyin

>
>     >     I am a regular reader of Eric Allen's series at IBM
>     > devoloperWorks.
>     > In his newest article
>     > (http://www-106.ibm.com/developerworks/java/library/j-diag
>     > 0612.html) he
>     > intermingles test code with production code. In my
>     > opinion, this has a bad
>     > smell, but ... well, I am interested of your opinion as I
>     > am not to sure if
>     > I am right.
>
> Actually, I thought it was a *neat* idea, if needed.  He points out to
> places where the need for this might be apparent, you decide on the need.
> Recorder is just a special case of a listener.  You don't have to
implement
> it the way Eric did, I think his implementation is a case of DTSTTCPW for
> his article.  More than likely, if you wanted some kind of Recorder like
> this you would have an update method on the observed classes that would
> cause the observer(s) to update itself.  If you wanted to get specific
> information about the class that is updating (like the method name), you
> could use the second parameter of the update method from the Observer
> interface.  Or if you have need of that param for something else, use
double
> dispatching to call back on the observable.
>
> In short, it's a bad smell if you don't need it (either through his
> implementation or through your own).
>
> -Jason
